a eunuch; by implication, valet (especially of the female apartments), and thus, a minister of state
properly, to hedge about (as with thorns), i.e. guard; generally, to protect, attend to, etc.
a vestibule (as a limit); also a dish (for holding blood or wine)
to search out (by any method, specifically in worship or prayer); by implication, to strive after
to send away, for, or out (in a great variety of applications)
a hand (the open one (indicating power, means, direction, etc.),
Achashverosh (i.e. Ahasuerus or Artaxerxes, but in this case Xerxes), the title (rather than name) of a Persian king

22.brief: to know (properly, to ascertain by seeing); used in a great variety of senses, figuratively, literally, euphemistically and inferentially (including observation, care, recognition; and causatively, instruction, designation, punishment, etc.)
a word; by implication, a matter (as spoken of) or thing; adverbially, a cause

properly, to front, i.e. stand boldly out opposite; by implication (causatively), to manifest; figuratively, to announce (always by word of mouth to one present); specifically, to expose, predict, explain, praise
an appellation, as amark or memorial of individuality; by implication honor, authority, character

23.brief: to search out (by any method, specifically in worship or prayer); by implication, to strive after
a word; by implication, a matter (as spoken of) or thing; adverbially, a cause
properly, to come forth to, i.e. appear or exist; transitively, to attain, i.e. find or acquire; figuratively, to occur, meet or be present
above, over, upon, or against (yet always in this last relation with a downward aspect) in a great variety of applications
a tree (from its firmness); hence, wood (plural sticks)
to grave, by implication, to write (describe, inscribe, prescribe, subscribe)
properly, writing (the art or a document); by implication, a book
a word; by implication, a matter (as spoken of) or thing; adverbially, a cause
a day (as the warm hours), whether literal (from sunrise to sunset, or from one sunset to the next), or figurative (a space of time defined by an associated term), (often used adverb)
the face (as the part that turns); used in a great variety of applications (literally and figuratively); also (with prepositional prefix) as a preposition (before, etc.)
